title: Thin film - light on soap bubble at P and Q

content.question: A soap bubble consists of an approximately spherical shape made from a thin layer of soapy water, with air on each side of the thin layer, as shown in the figure. For light of wavelength <math alttext="lambda sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>λ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> that is normally incident at point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>, the soapy water layer is the minimum thickness <math alttext="t sub min" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>min</mi></msub></math> needed for there to be maximum constructive interference of the light reflected from the two water-air interfaces. At point <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi></math>, the soapy water layer has a different thickness, but there is still maximum constructive interference of the reflections from the two interfaces when light of the same wavelength <math alttext="lambda sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>λ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> is normally incident on the bubble. Which of the following could be the smallest possible thickness of the layer at point <math alttext="Q" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Q</mi></math>?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
